author: cashflow_
body: I remember a teacher saying in class once, if you hear hooves at night why do you guys think it’s a zebra. She meant instead of a horse. I think that’s how my brains works. Might be legit regarded

author: Zealousideal-Hunt343
body:
Buy the furthest option you can. You can buy a few more years with a little extra.  
Do your rolling when expiration is in a year.

Another thing you might want to look at is a ZEBRA.  

[https://www.tastytrade.com/definitions/zebra](https://www.tastytrade.com/definitions/zebra)

This will eliminate the extrinsic value you pay for the long positions by shorts. However, you might need a little extra capital.

author: Calamino
body: Does it rhyme with Willow the Zebra? I read that article last night too.

author: fugaltulip
body: Look into the ZEBRA strategy (zero extrinsic back ratio spread)—since there is no extrinsic value, there can be no IV crush. You do have to be right on the direction though. It’s my favorite strategy of all time because you basically have 0 exposure to theta and vega and just need to worry about the stock price.

author: CCChristopherson
body: I struggled with this for awhile. My current strategy is don’t buy unless there is some type of retreat of at least a few percentage points, but don’t be bothered by the fact that you’re up quite a bit on the position overall.  For example, ZBRA has done well for me since January, but I didn’t start buying more until it started tanking a few weeks ago. I was still up 50% overall when I bought, but I bought when it was down 10% so it felt better. Others might say that if you like the stock long term then just buy it regardless of recent price action, but my brain is incapable of that so I’m left with this strategy

author: CCChristopherson
body:
I get that completely. There’s one thing I forgot to mentioned that has helped, just keep in mind this only works for profitable companies.

Instead of just looking at the price, look at the historic P/E ratio (which you can add easily to the price chart on Ameritrade). So going back to my ZBRA example, it had a PE of 41 on January 1st.  I was up 40-50% when I bought more in September, but the P/E at that time was around 37. So I’m paying more, but it’s kind of like I’m getting a better deal. That’s just something that’s helped me justify averaging up when I like a stock so maybe check that out for profitable companies

author: MohJeex
body: Put debit spreads are cheap on SPY due to its aggressive skew (they're like almost half the price of an equal call debit spread .. that's how much skewed SPY is). That would be one option to hedge cheaply. Also, a ZEBRA option strategy (selling 1 OTM put and buying 2 ITM puts .. you can structure them to get -100 deltas) is again very good if you really want downside protection (but they will obviously cost more). You can even sell a covered call if you have 100 SPY to reduce the cost of doing either one of these.

author: botrickbateman
body:
The basement has one couple in it who look like Sam and Ilene Sanford but it’s darker down here, *warmer*, and I could be wrong. I move past them as they stand by the bar drinking champagne and head over toward this extremely well-dressed Mexican-looking guy sitting on a couch. He’s wearing a double-breasted wool jacket and matching trousers by Mario Valentino, a cotton T-shirt by Agnes B. and leather slip-ons (no socks) by Susan Bennis Warren Edwards, and he’s with a goodlooking muscular Eurotrash chick—dirty blond, big tits, tan, no makeup, smoking Merit Ultra Lights—who has on a cotton gown with a zebra print by Patrick Kelly and silk and rhinestone high-heeled pumps.

___

^(*Bot. Ask me what I’m doing.* |) [^(Opt out)](https://www.reddit.com/message/compose/?to=botrickbateman&subject=Opt%20out)

author: TQQQ_Gang
body: Do deep ITM LEAPS, ZEBRA, or bull call spread if you want more leverage on TQQQ. TQQQ will generally have high margin requirements and you'll just get margin called.
